item.title: SyncNote Alpha Dev Release
item.content:encoded:
I am happy to announce the alpha release of SyncNote, a simple notes app for Android and PC which lets you easily synchronize your notes between your mobile and PC devices. The app is developed using Jetpack Compose and Jetbrains Compose Desktop for the JVM release, I used Kotlin Multiplatform to share source-code between platforms. I developed this app during the last few months as a personal exercise.

You can see the source code at: GitHub
item.description: SyncNote Kotlin sources are now up on GitHub!
item.author: Patrik Eriksson

item.title: An new, easier way of improving JVM-startup time using Java 19
item.content:encoded:
Dynamic CDS has been available with since Java JDK version 12. Depending on your program, enabling it can result in slight startup-time improvement, or even > 3x for larger applications. I recommend using in order to improve startup time for all your Java programs. Enabling dynamic CDS usually involves first adding a flag in the java startup command for initial creation of the archive, such as:

java -XX:ArchiveClassesAtExit=archive.jsa -jar yourapp.jar

The shared class data file archive be written as archive.jsa in your current directory. Then, to enable use of CDS, after the previous step you have to supply a different flag in order to load and use the archive, on all subsequent runs:

java -XX:SharedArchiveFile=archive.jsa -jar yourapp.jar

After jumping through these hoops you could finally enjoy faster startup times.

But wait thereâ€™s more! It seems that using 2 steps in order achieve this functionality would be redundant. Oracle has thought of us developers and made our lives slightly easier: starting from Java 19, developers can use a new flag called -XX:AutoCreateSharedArchive together with previously existing -XX:SharedArchiveFile=.

Now, we can simply run a single command to save us some and effort, the archive will be created after first run and exit of the application. After the first run, the archive will be loaded automatically and used during class loading. Just enter both flags in your Java startup command:

java -XX:+AutoCreateSharedArchive -XX:SharedArchiveFile=archive.jsa -jar yourapp.jar

Enjoy your fast JVM startups! Using just 1 command!
item.description: Java 19 adds new JVM startup flags for enabling Dynamic CDS archives
item.author: Patrik Eriksson
